text:
S-X2
338. Reesor, Bessie Myrtle (Mrs. P.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: BESSIE M. REESOR
Address: CONSEL SASK.
Birthplace: ROCKHILL IND.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1913
Where did you set up housekeeping? NE M 4 - 27
Where had you been living before that? With my mother (miles from here)
For how many people did you prepare meals? My husband and family 2
How far was it to your nearest store? Five miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? As often as we liked
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Most all of the staple groceries available today.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Maple Leaf
In what quantities did you buy it? Usually in 100 lb. lots
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? From $6.00 to $8.00
How much did you use graham flour? Ruskens around 20 lbs
Whole wheat flour? Ruskens around 20 lbs
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? 52 miles What year? 1910
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 20¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes Whole Wheat? Yes Farina? Yes
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Occasionally
How did you grind it? With a small food grinder
PIONEER DIET! WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

1. INSTRUCTORS QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1913.

Where did you set up housekeeping? [Blank]

Where had you been living before that? [Blank]

For how many people did you prepare meals? [Blank]

How far was it to your nearest store? [Blank]

How often could a visit be made to the store? [Blank]

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? [Blank]

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What breed of cattle did you use in the early years? [Blank]

In what quantities did you buy? [Blank]

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? [Blank]

How much did you use Graham flour? [Blank]

Whole wheat flour? [Blank]

Was flour milled locally? [Blank]

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? [Blank]

What other grain products did you use? [Blank]

Cornmeal? [Blank]

Other? [Blank]

Did you grind your own wheat for personal use? [Blank]

How did you grind it? [Blank]
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lb lot.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 70¢.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Regina.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 oz.
At what price? 60¢.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We always had our own dairy cows.
Butter? Our own butter.
Eggs? Our own eggs.
What was the price of butter from 1875 to 1925? 10¢ per lb.
Did you pack eggs for market? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
Did you make cheese? Yes.
What kind of cheese? Ordinary yellow cheese made with sour milk.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, mutton, pork, poultry of every kind.
How did you get fresh meat? We canned and cured meat for summer use.
How often did you get fresh meat? Whenever felt it advisable to kill.
How did you preserve meat? By canning & curing.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not until 1930.
If so, what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Occasionally.
What kinds? Antelope deer, quail, quail, quail, chicken, sage hens.
For how long? Just during the gun fall season.
What part did fish play in the family diet? We always used frozen fish during the winter months.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned & cured salmon.
Kinds? Salmon, smelt, pickerel, etc.
3. Are you aware of the fact that the quantity of flour used in making bread has been reduced by about 25%?

4. Did you ever eat any kind of bread made from flour containing added vitamin E?

5. How often did you eat fresh fruits and vegetables?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Salad... at what price? 38¢
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Mottley... how much? early days
Price? Hi-Temp... other beverages were used? 2¢
Chocolate, rootin, some lime...

7. VEGETABLES AND FRUIT PURCHASES

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
$1.00... Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes...
If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of 1913-1914?
Potatoes 1913, Cabbage 1913, Carrots 1913, Onions 1913,
Turnips 1913, Beets 1913.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 1 lb...
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk...
That weight? 2 lbs... did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes...
That was the price of prunes? 10¢...
That other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (aples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes...
peas? Yes... corn? Yes... beans? Yes... Saskatoons? No...
other foods? No...

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1913...
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920...
That year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1914...
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes... every little
can, can just little meat for variety... some vegetables as
plus from the garden...
To what extent? We have a program fairly close to today's plant...
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes... in early days...
5. BEST VEGETABLES

What kind of tea did you buy? (Tea or coffee) ________ ________

Price ________ ________

Did you buy other beverages? ________

6. VEGETABLES AND FRUITS

There was no record of potatoes per bushel, how many did you purchase?

If not, where from ________

Did you get potatoes at the store? ________

Price ________

7. VEGETABLES AND FRUITS

In what quantities did you buy white turnips? ________

How did you buy onions? (In bulk or by the head?) ________

Price ________

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by boiling? ________

Did you first press two fruits by canning? ________

Did you first press vegetables by canning? ________

Did you still preserve foods by another method? ________

Did you make jam or jelly? ________

Did you make any other preserves? ________

B. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal yeast cakes
Did you make yeast for your own use? Using starter? X
Using hops? Salt rising?
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Did you make your own baking powder? No

10. What types of yeast did you use? ________
   11. Did you make yeast for your own use? ________
   12. Did you buy baking powder? ________
   13. Did you make your own baking powder? ________

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) River until 1934 when we dug a well.

How far was this water from your home? River just a short distance.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel daily.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In 1934 we dug a well & have the water piped into the kitchen. It being hard water, we installed a cistern for soft water.

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|-------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|

| Icing sugar                 | 1920                                   |                               |                                                 |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Were did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout). **New Well 1934** when we dug a well.

How far was this water from your home? **Kissel Ford short distance**

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **Lavatory, ideally**

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In 1934 we dug a well & put its water piped into the kitchen.

At burying ground nearby, we installed a cistern for soft water.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made our own mostly.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? P.G. Felo Myrtha

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal and wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Wanted wood from Cypress Hills 25 miles away. Coal from mine 90 miles until 1941 it has been shipped in.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We still have a coal or wood range, also have a gasoline stove.

Installed an oil burner in 1951.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Quincy Oxford.

What year was it purchased? 1918. Price? $75.00.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) We used all these in utensils.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) We used all of these.

When did you first see enamel ware? 1910.

Aluminum? 1918.
13. STOVES
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? (Describe, etc., and locality.)
If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes/No
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? (e.g., Flora, Hypo, etc.)

14. FUEL
What fuel did you use in the earliest days? (Describe, etc., and locality.)
Where did you get your fuel? (Describe, etc., and locality.)
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

You still have a wood-burning stove, also have a gasoline stove. Installed an oil burner in 1951.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made?
What year was it purchased?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

I notice we have more plastic wrappings & containers of late years, replacing the ordinary paper bags. I really cannot give date when changes were made.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast:
Bacon & eggs
Waffles
Jam & coffee

Roast beef
Potatoes
Vegetable gravy
Pine pudding

Supper:
Cold meat, rice, fruit & warm potatoes
Salad
Cake & tea

This is a type of meals I served when first married. They are much the same today except lighter breakfasts and suppers generally meet once each day.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1914

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Roast Goose & dressing
Mashed Potatoes
Gravy
Parsnips
Cabbage salad
Home-made pickles
Minced pie & coffee
Homemade candy nuts

Mother & stepfather Mr. & Mrs. Geo. Clydesley
ages 74 & 76
Husband & wife age 35
Daughters Margaret age 12
Estella, Estelle, Lois age 11
Bertha, Ben & Willie age 10 & 4

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No.

We grew most of our own vegetables, meat etc. since I can remember, always have had milk, butter, eggs etc.
16. **WEAPONS AND ORNAMENTS**
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible), and describe any new utensils or tools used.

17. **GIVE A TYPICAL DAY'S MENU**
Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., January.

18. **WHAT YEAR DID YOU SERVE YOUR FIRST CHRISTMAS DINNER IN WESTERN OKLAHOMA?**
Give the date.

19. **WERE YOU EVER REDUCED TO ALMOST STARVATION LEVEL LIVING ON ONE OR TWO LOCALLY PRODUCED FOODS?**
Give details.

20. **DO YOU THINK THAT THE FOODS AVAILABLE TODAY ARE MORE NUTRITIOUS THAN THOSE AVAILABLE THEN?**
Give reasons.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the earliest and earlier days we had no fridges, so we did have ice from the first year. We had an ice box until 1952. We were more frozen desserts also foods from the cooler and house salads before we eat less meat than in earlier years.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Generally speaking, we still use home prepared and homegrown foods. I still bake bread & biscuits. We buy more than in early days. We are able to get fresh bread here or more often, so we do quite often do so.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I might add when we were first married my husband dug a root cellar. We still have one and are able to keep vegetables fresh all winter. Have had turnips, parsnips, cabbages, beets, carrots, potatoes every year in the 40s. Also had a smoke house to smoke meats in early years. However, we do not do that of late years. We have always had a milk house with tank for ice where all dairy products could be kept in the summer.

I feel we have been fortunate in these ways as I realize many throughout this district have not had those things the of late years. The greater percent are getting fridges and modern equipment.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the earlier and earlier days we had no electricity or running water. We did have ice from the frozen well, but we also had to rely on home grown vegetables and fruits. We also had to rely on home grown flour and sugar. We did not have the convenience of modern appliances.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods?

Generally speaking, we still use home grown vegetables and fruits. However, in the early days, we also used to rely on purchased foods. We did not have the convenience of modern appliances.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, types of storage, shortages, and other details. (Use back of pages if more space is needed).

I might add when we were first married my husband dug a root cellar. We still have one and add a little bit of vegetables fresh all winter. Have Paul Turner's (name) cabbage rolls, carrots, potatoes every year. In the 40s, also had a little bit of meat. We always had a milk house that did not last long. We have always had a milk house with tame for our own dairy products until he kept in the summer.

If we have been fortunate in these ways so I realize many things over the decades here not had these things the 40s years. The quicker you can get your fridges and modern equipment.
